properties.areaDesc: South and Southeast Grand/West Central and Southwest Boulder/Gilpin/Clear Creek/Summit/North and West Park Counties Above 9000 Feet; South and East Jackson/Larimer/North and Northeast Grand/Northwest Boulder Counties Above 9000 Feet
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 1 at 4:01AM MST until January 3 at 12:00AM MST by NWS Denver CO
properties.description:
...A ROUND OF SNOW AND HAZARDOUS WINTER TRAVEL CONDITIONS FOR THE
NORTHERN MOUNTAINS...

.Snow will develop in the northern mountains of Colorado
this morning and become widespread and heavier by early
afternoon. Another increase in snowfall rates will occur this
evening before tapering off overnight. Light snow will continue
through Thursday. Gusty winds of 40 to 55 mph will also produce
blowing and drifting snow and reduced visibilities, in exposed
areas, and over the higher mountain passes. The heaviest totals
can be expected in the mountains north of Rabbit Ears Pass, with
moderate snowfall totals, in the Front Range Mountains and Summit
County.

* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 3 to 9
inches. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph.

* WHERE...The Mountains of Summit County, the Mosquito Range,
and the Indian Peaks and Rocky Mountain National Park and the
Medicine Bow Range.

* WHEN...From noon today to midnight MST Thursday night.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Patchy blowing snow
could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous
conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Strong
winds could cause tree damage. The cold wind chills as low as
20 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as
little as 30 minutes.
properties.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

NWSheadline: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TODAY TO MIDNIGHT MST THURSDAY NIGHT
